title: Ezekiel Chapter 30 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 30 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 30 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 30.

questions.question: Who is commanded to prophesy in Ezekiel 30?
options: Son of man
Pharaoh
Nebuchadrezzar
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: Son of man
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:2 states, 'Son of man, prophesy and say...,' showing that the command is given to the Son of man.

questions.question: What kind of day is described in Ezekiel 30:3 as the day of the LORD?
options: A cloudy day
A sunny day
A stormy day
A bright day
questions.correctAnswer: A cloudy day
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:3 says, '...the day of the LORD is near, a cloudy day; it shall be the time of the heathen.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 30:10, by whose hand will the multitude of Egypt cease?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
Pharaoh king of Egypt
The king of Lydia
The prophet Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:10 states, 'I will also make the multitude of Egypt to cease by the hand of Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon.'

questions.question: Which land will be desolate in the midst of other desolate countries according to Ezekiel 30:7?
options: Egypt
Babylon
Ethiopia
Lydia
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:7 says, 'And they shall be desolate in the midst of the countries that are desolate, and her cities shall be in the midst of the cities that are wasted.' The 'they' refers to Egypt.

questions.question: What will happen to the idols and images in Noph as declared in Ezekiel 30?
options: They will be destroyed
They will be worshiped more
They will be moved to another land
They will be hidden
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:13 states, 'I will also destroy the idols, and I will cause their images to cease out of Noph.'

questions.question: What will happen to the young men of Aven and Pibeseth according to Ezekiel 30:17?
options: They shall fall by the sword
They shall become kings
They shall be healed
They shall escape captivity
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fall by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:17 says, 'The young men of Aven and of Pibeseth shall fall by the sword.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 30:21, what has happened to Pharaoh king of Egypt's arm?
options: It has been broken
It has been healed
It has grown stronger
It has been blessed
questions.correctAnswer: It has been broken
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:21 states, 'Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh king of Egypt.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 30:12 says the LORD will make the rivers dry and the land waste by the hand of strangers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:12 clearly says, 'And I will make the rivers dry...and all that is therein, by the hand of strangers.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 30:26 says the Egyptians will be scattered among the nations and dispersed among the countries.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:26 states, 'And I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and disperse them among the countries.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 30:8, the LORD will set a fire in Egypt and all her helpers shall be destroyed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:8 says, 'And they shall know that I am the LORD, when I have set a fire in Egypt, and when all her helpers shall be destroyed.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 30:22: 'Behold, I am against Pharaoh king of Egypt, and will break his arms, the strong, and that which was broken; and I will cause the sword to fall out of his ______.'
options: hand
mouth
foot
eye
questions.correctAnswer: hand
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:22 says, '...and I will cause the sword to fall out of his hand.'

questions.question: Which cities does God specifically mention setting fire to in Ezekiel 30:14?
options: Zoan and Pathros
Thebes and Memphis
Jerusalem and Babylon
Sin and No
questions.correctAnswer: Zoan and Pathros
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:14 states, 'I will make Pathros desolate, and will set fire in Zoan.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 30:24, whose arms will be strengthened and whose arms will be broken?
options: King of Babylon strengthened, Pharaoh's arms broken
Pharaoh's arms strengthened, King of Babylon's broken
Both Pharaoh's and Babylon's arms strengthened
Both Pharaoh's and Babylon's arms broken
questions.correctAnswer: King of Babylon strengthened, Pharaoh's arms broken
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:24 says, 'I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon... but I will break Pharaoh's arms.'

questions.question: Who is described as 'the terrible of the nations' in Ezekiel 30:11?
options: Nebuchadrezzar and his people
Pharaoh and his army
The men of Lydia
The priests of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar and his people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:11 states, 'He and his people with him, the terrible of the nations,' referring to Nebuchadrezzar and his army.

questions.question: Which of these places is NOT mentioned in Ezekiel 30 as being affected by judgment?
options: Jerusalem
Sin
No
Noph
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jerusalem is not mentioned in Ezekiel 30; the chapter focuses on Egypt and its cities such as Sin, No, and Noph.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 30 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 30 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezekiel 30, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during times of judgment?
options: God is sovereign and His judgments serve to reveal His power and purpose.
Human strength alone will overcome all trials without God's intervention.
Suffering means God has abandoned His people permanently.
Judgment is random and without meaning.
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign and His judgments serve to reveal His power and purpose.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:8, 19, 26 show that God's judgment serves a purpose: to make nations know He is the LORD. Believers can trust God's sovereignty even in adversity.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 teach about humility when facing personal or national crises?
options: Pride leads to downfall and God humbles the arrogant.
Humility is unnecessary because human strength is enough.
Crises should be ignored and not connected to spiritual causes.
Only physical strength matters in overcoming hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and God humbles the arrogant.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:6 speaks of the pride of Egypt’s power coming down. This teaches humility before God’s judgment.

questions.question: In the context of Ezekiel 30, what can we learn about perseverance through trials?
options: God’s purposes prevail and trials refine faith and dependence on Him.
Trials are meaningless and should be avoided at all cost.
Perseverance depends only on human effort, not divine help.
Suffering is a sign of God’s rejection without hope for restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s purposes prevail and trials refine faith and dependence on Him.
questions.explanation: Verses like Ezekiel 30:4-5 and 30:12 show that God’s judgment is purposeful. Believers are called to trust God’s plan amid adversity.

questions.question: A believer struggles with fear about future uncertainties. Based on Ezekiel 30, what biblical truth about God’s control can you share?
options: God controls the outcome of nations and individuals; His power is supreme.
Fear should be ignored because God has no control over events.
Only human strategies determine the future.
Uncertainty means God is indifferent to people’s lives.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the outcome of nations and individuals; His power is supreme.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:10-11, 24-25 show God strengthening Babylon and breaking Pharaoh’s arms, emphasizing divine sovereignty over history.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 emphasize the importance of trusting God rather than human alliances?
options: Those who support Egypt will fall, showing that human alliances cannot save.
Human alliances are always reliable and should be trusted above God.
God encourages reliance on political power alone.
God has no involvement in human alliances.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who support Egypt will fall, showing that human alliances cannot save.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:5-6 declares that Ethiopia, Libya, and allies of Egypt will fall, teaching that trust must be in God, not in earthly alliances.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30 teach about God’s justice and the consequences of sin?
options: God executes judgment to bring awareness and correction.
Sin has no consequences and God overlooks injustice.
Justice is arbitrary and unrelated to human behavior.
God’s justice only applies to other nations, not His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God executes judgment to bring awareness and correction.
questions.explanation: Verses such as Ezekiel 30:13-14 and 30:19 describe God's judgments as purposeful actions to make people know He is the LORD.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness toward others who have wronged them. Based on Ezekiel 30, what biblical principle could help them respond rightly?
options: Recognize God’s justice will prevail and focus on humility and faith.
Harbor resentment because justice is not served on earth.
Take vengeance personally rather than trusting God.
Ignore God’s role in justice and act only by human means.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s justice will prevail and focus on humility and faith.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:21-25 illustrates God breaking Pharaoh’s strength and empowering Babylon, showing that God controls justice and calls for humble trust.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 30 teaches that God’s judgments are designed to result in repentance and acknowledgment of His sovereignty.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:8, 19, and 26 show that through judgment, people will know that God is the LORD, indicating a purpose toward repentance and recognition.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 30, human pride and power can ultimately withstand God’s judgment and remain unbroken.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:6 and 30:21-22 describe the breaking down of Egypt’s pride and Pharaoh’s arm, showing that pride cannot withstand God’s judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 30:11 says, 'He and his people with him, the terrible of the nations, shall be brought to destroy the land: and they shall draw their swords against _______, and fill the land with the slain.'
options: Egypt
Babylon
Ethiopia
Sin
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: The passage specifically states that the sword will be drawn against Egypt, emphasizing the coming judgment on that nation.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 30, how can believers apply the lesson of God 'breaking the arm' of Pharaoh (Ezekiel 30:21) to their own spiritual walk?
options: Trust God to weaken any spiritual opposition and not rely on their own strength.
Rely solely on their own power to overcome challenges.
Ignore spiritual battles as irrelevant.
Focus only on material success as a sign of God’s favor.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to weaken any spiritual opposition and not rely on their own strength.
questions.explanation: The imagery of God breaking Pharaoh’s arm (Ezekiel 30:21-22) teaches believers to depend on God’s power over adversaries rather than their own strength.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30 teach about the importance of recognizing God’s hand in national and personal calamities?
options: God’s involvement is clear and should lead to repentance and faith.
Calamities happen randomly without divine purpose.
Only human factors cause calamities, not God.
God’s hand is hidden and unknowable in hardships.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s involvement is clear and should lead to repentance and faith.
questions.explanation: Verses like Ezekiel 30:7-9 and 30:19 emphasize that God sets fires and sends messengers, making His involvement evident to bring people back to Him.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in their daily lives despite challenges?
options: By trusting God’s justice and remaining faithful even when circumstances are difficult.
By compromising when under pressure to avoid trouble.
By ignoring God’s commands when life is hard.
By focusing only on personal gain regardless of ethics.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s justice and remaining faithful even when circumstances are difficult.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30 teaches that God’s justice will prevail (verses 10-12, 24-25), encouraging believers to remain faithful and honest despite trials.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 30, God promises to scatter the Egyptians among the nations (verses 23 and 26). What practical application about humility and dependence can believers draw from this?
options: Humility before God and dependence on Him prevent downfall and scattering.
Self-reliance always leads to success and honor.
Pride protects a person from adverse circumstances.
Ignoring God’s commands has no consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: Humility before God and dependence on Him prevent downfall and scattering.
questions.explanation: The scattering of Egypt shows consequences of pride and disobedience, teaching believers to remain humble and dependent on God (Ezekiel 30:23, 26).

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 30, how should believers respond to the destruction of idols and false images mentioned in verse 13?
options: By focusing their worship solely on the one true God and rejecting false gods.
By tolerating idolatry as part of culture.
By relying on images for protection and blessing.
By ignoring spiritual purity in worship.
questions.correctAnswer: By focusing their worship solely on the one true God and rejecting false gods.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:13 shows God’s judgment against idols, teaching believers to worship God alone and reject idolatry.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 30 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 30.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 30, what is the significance of the 'day of the LORD' being described as a 'cloudy day'?
options: It symbolizes judgment and darkness over the nations
It represents a time of great harvest and blessing
It indicates a day of peace and restoration
It refers to a literal weather event in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes judgment and darkness over the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:3 describes the day of the LORD as a 'cloudy day,' symbolizing a time of judgment and calamity for the heathen nations.

questions.question: Which foreign king is prophesied to bring judgment upon Egypt in Ezekiel 30?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
Cyrus king of Persia
Pharaoh of Egypt
Darius king of Media
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:10 explicitly states that Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon will bring destruction upon Egypt.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Ezekiel 30:5, where multiple nations including Ethiopia, Libya, Lydia, and others fall by the sword together?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Typology
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The listing of nations falling together in Ezekiel 30:5 is an example of parallelism, emphasizing collective judgment.

questions.question: What does the breaking of Pharaoh’s arm symbolize in Ezekiel 30?
options: Loss of power and military strength
Physical injury during battle
Recovery and healing of Egypt
Pharaoh’s death
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of power and military strength
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:21-22 uses the metaphor of breaking Pharaoh’s arm to symbolize the loss of his strength and inability to wield the sword, indicating military defeat.

questions.question: How does the prophecy against Egypt in Ezekiel 30 foreshadow later biblical themes of divine judgment against nations?
options: It anticipates the universal sovereignty of God over all nations
It predicts the immediate restoration of Egypt
It limits God’s power to Israel only
It rejects the idea of divine punishment
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the universal sovereignty of God over all nations
questions.explanation: The judgment on Egypt in Ezekiel 30 underscores God’s control over all nations, a theme that develops throughout Scripture (e.g., Isaiah 40:22-23).

questions.question: Which cities in Egypt are specifically mentioned as sites of divine judgment in Ezekiel 30?
options: Pathros, Zoan, No, Sin, Noph, Aven, Pibeseth, Tehaphnehes
Jerusalem, Hebron, Bethlehem, Jericho
Tyre, Sidon, Damascus, Babylon
Nineveh, Haran, Sodom, Gomorrah
questions.correctAnswer: Pathros, Zoan, No, Sin, Noph, Aven, Pibeseth, Tehaphnehes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:14-18 lists these specific Egyptian cities as targets of judgment, reflecting their political and religious significance.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 30 describes the destruction of idols and images in Egypt as part of God's judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:13 states that God will destroy the idols and cause their images to cease in Noph, indicating judgment against idolatry.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'I will make the rivers dry' in Ezekiel 30:12 signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Economic and agricultural devastation
A literal drought lasting decades
A spiritual cleansing ritual
A prophecy of flooding
questions.correctAnswer: Economic and agricultural devastation
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, rivers were lifelines for agriculture and trade; drying them symbolizes total ruin of the land’s productivity (Ezekiel 30:12).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 use the motif of 'fire' in relation to Egypt?
options: As a symbol of divine wrath and destruction
As a symbol of purification and renewal
As a literal wildfire destroying crops
As a festival celebration
questions.correctAnswer: As a symbol of divine wrath and destruction
questions.explanation: Multiple verses (e.g., Ezekiel 30:8, 14, 16) mention setting fire in Egypt, symbolizing God's judgment and wrath consuming the land.

questions.question: What is the theological purpose of emphasizing that Egypt and its allies will 'know that I am the LORD' in this chapter?
options: To affirm God's sovereignty and justice over nations
To declare the end of God's involvement in human affairs
To predict Egypt's conversion to monotheism
To encourage military alliance with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To affirm God's sovereignty and justice over nations
questions.explanation: This phrase, repeated in Ezekiel 30:8, 19, 25, highlights that God's judgments serve to reveal His supreme authority.

questions.question: Which literary structure is evident in Ezekiel 30's sequence of judgments against various cities and peoples?
options: A prophetic oracle with a progressive lament and judgment sequence
A historical narrative with chronological events
A parable with a moral lesson
An epistle with personal exhortations
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic oracle with a progressive lament and judgment sequence
questions.explanation: The chapter follows a pattern common in prophetic oracles: call to lament, announcement of judgment, and detailed descriptions of destruction.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'howl' in Ezekiel 30:2 imply in the prophetic context?
options: A loud lamentation expressing grief and terror
A joyful shout of victory
A silent prayer
A ritual dance
questions.correctAnswer: A loud lamentation expressing grief and terror
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word used conveys a mournful, intense cry signaling impending disaster (Ezekiel 30:2).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 relate to the earlier prophecies against Egypt in Isaiah 19?
options: Both prophesy judgment and destruction of Egypt due to idolatry and alliances
Isaiah predicts Egypt's permanent victory, Ezekiel predicts peace
Ezekiel focuses on Babylon, Isaiah focuses on Persia
They have no thematic or prophetic connection
questions.correctAnswer: Both prophesy judgment and destruction of Egypt due to idolatry and alliances
questions.explanation: Isaiah 19 and Ezekiel 30 share themes of divine judgment on Egypt for its idolatry and political alliances, reflecting a consistent prophetic tradition.

questions.question: What cultural significance did the cities of No, Zoan, and Noph hold in ancient Egypt, as referenced in Ezekiel 30?
options: They were major religious and political centers
They were small villages with no importance
They were Babylonian colonies in Egypt
They were symbolic names for Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They were major religious and political centers
questions.explanation: These cities were important seats of power and worship in Egypt, making their judgment symbolically significant (Ezekiel 30:14-16).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 30 predicts that the Egyptians will be scattered among the nations as a consequence of their judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:23 and 30:26 clearly state that God will scatter the Egyptians among the nations as part of their punishment.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 30 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 30 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary event prophesied in Ezekiel 30 concerning Egypt and surrounding nations?
options: The destruction of Egypt and allied nations by the sword
The restoration of Egypt's former glory
The peaceful alliance of Egypt with Babylon
The rise of Egypt as a global power
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Egypt and allied nations by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:4-6 foretells the sword coming upon Egypt and the fall of Ethiopia, Libya, and other allied nations. This judgment aligns with God's sovereign judgment seen in Isaiah 19:1-4, Jeremiah 46:25-26, Nahum 3:8-10, and Revelation 16:12-16, where God executes justice on nations opposing His will.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 30, who is appointed as the instrument of God's judgment against Egypt?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
Cyrus king of Persia
Pharaoh king of Egypt
The king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:10-11 identifies Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon as the hand by which God will bring devastation upon Egypt. This is consistent with Jeremiah 25:9 and Daniel 2:37-38, where Babylon is God's instrument for judgment, fulfilling the theme of divine sovereignty over empires.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase ‘the day of the LORD’ as used in Ezekiel 30:3?
options: It signifies a time of divine judgment and reckoning
It denotes a day of national celebration
It refers to the creation of the world
It marks the coronation of a king
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies a time of divine judgment and reckoning
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:3 describes the day of the LORD as near and cloudy, indicating judgment. This theological motif is present throughout Scripture as a day when God executes justice (Joel 2:1-2, Amos 5:18-20, Zephaniah 1:14-18, 1 Thessalonians 5:2-4).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 30, what will happen to the idols and images in Egypt?
options: They will be destroyed and cease to exist
They will be preserved as cultural artifacts
They will be relocated to Babylon
They will be worshiped by neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and cease to exist
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:13 states that God will destroy the idols and cause their images to cease out of Noph. This reflects God's intolerance of idolatry as seen in Exodus 20:4-5, Isaiah 44:9-20, Psalm 115:4-8, and Acts 17:29, emphasizing His holiness and demand for exclusive worship.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30 teach about God’s sovereignty over nations and rulers?
options: God raises and breaks the arms of kings according to His will
God has no authority over earthly rulers
Kings rule independently of God’s plans
God only judges individuals, not nations
questions.correctAnswer: God raises and breaks the arms of kings according to His will
questions.explanation: Verses 21-25 describe God breaking Pharaoh’s arms and strengthening Babylon’s, showing divine control over rulers. This doctrine is affirmed in Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1, Proverbs 21:1, and Isaiah 45:1, teaching that God ordains and restrains earthly powers.

questions.question: Which cities in Egypt are mentioned in Ezekiel 30 as facing judgment and desolation?
options: Pathros, Zoan, No, Sin, Noph
Jerusalem, Samaria, Tyre, Sidon
Babylon, Nineveh, Damascus, Tyre
Hebron, Bethel, Ai, Gibeon
questions.correctAnswer: Pathros, Zoan, No, Sin, Noph
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:14-16 names these cities as targets of divine judgment. This illustrates God's comprehensive judgment on Egypt’s political and religious centers, paralleling judgments on cities in Isaiah 19:18-22 and Jeremiah 46:25-26.

questions.question: What theological truth is emphasized by the repeated phrase ‘and they shall know that I am the LORD’ in Ezekiel 30?
options: God’s judgments reveal His sovereignty and holiness
God’s name will be forgotten among the nations
Human wisdom surpasses God’s authority
God is indifferent to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgments reveal His sovereignty and holiness
questions.explanation: The phrase appears in verses 8, 19, 25, and 26, underscoring that God’s actions serve to demonstrate His divine authority to all. This theme aligns with Exodus 6:7, Ezekiel 36:23, Psalm 46:10, and John 17:3, highlighting God’s self-revelation through judgment and salvation.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30 indicate about the fate of the Egyptians after judgment?
options: They will be scattered among the nations
They will remain united and strong
They will conquer Babylon
They will return to idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: They will be scattered among the nations
questions.explanation: Verses 23 and 26 declare that God will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, reflecting the biblical motif of exile as judgment (Genesis 12:3, Deuteronomy 28:64, 2 Kings 17:6, Luke 21:24). This dispersion serves as a consequence of rebellion and idolatry.

questions.question: What is the meaning of God saying He will ‘make the rivers dry’ and ‘sell the land into the hand of the wicked’ in Ezekiel 30:12?
options: Complete desolation and control by foreign powers will come upon Egypt
The land will become fertile and prosperous
Egypt will gain control over neighboring lands
God will bless Egypt with abundance
questions.correctAnswer: Complete desolation and control by foreign powers will come upon Egypt
questions.explanation: This imagery in Ezekiel 30:12 symbolizes total devastation and subjugation by outsiders, consistent with prophetic language in Isaiah 5:13, Jeremiah 9:11, Lamentations 4:3, and Habakkuk 1:6, where God uses nations to accomplish judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 depict God’s attitude towards Egypt’s ‘pride of her power’?
options: God will bring it low and break it down
God will elevate it to new heights
God will ignore it
God will reward it for its strength
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring it low and break it down
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:6 speaks of the pride of Egypt’s power coming down. This is consistent with biblical teaching about God humbling the proud (Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:12, Luke 1:52, James 4:6), showing His justice and holiness.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30 reveal about God’s justice in relation to idolatry and false security?
options: God will destroy idols and remove false confidence in Egypt’s strength
God will allow idols to remain as symbols of culture
God will bless those who trust in idols
God’s justice is unrelated to idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: God will destroy idols and remove false confidence in Egypt’s strength
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 30:13 and 30:15-16 show God’s judgment against idols and the places symbolizing Egypt’s strength. This reflects the biblical principle that God’s holiness demands rejection of idolatry (Deuteronomy 7:25-26, Isaiah 44:9-20, 1 Corinthians 10:14, Revelation 9:20).

questions.question: What eschatological theme is present in the announcement ‘Howl ye, Woe worth the day!’ in Ezekiel 30:2?
options: The imminent coming of divine judgment and the day of the LORD
The celebration of a feast day
The inauguration of a new temple
The birth of a messianic king
questions.correctAnswer: The imminent coming of divine judgment and the day of the LORD
questions.explanation: This lament introduces the theme of the day of the LORD as a time of judgment and distress (Joel 1:15, Amos 5:18, Zephaniah 1:14, Matthew 24:29), emphasizing the seriousness of God’s righteous judgment upon nations.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 30:22-24 teach about the relationship between God, Pharaoh, and Babylon?
options: God empowers Babylon to defeat Pharaoh and breaks Pharaoh’s strength
God supports Pharaoh against Babylon
Pharaoh will conquer Babylon by his own strength
Babylon will be destroyed by Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: God empowers Babylon to defeat Pharaoh and breaks Pharaoh’s strength
questions.explanation: These verses show God actively strengthening Babylon’s arms and weakening Pharaoh’s, demonstrating divine sovereignty over geopolitical conflicts (Isaiah 10:5-6, Daniel 2:21, Jeremiah 27:6, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Which best summarizes the reason God’s judgment is pronounced in Ezekiel 30 against Egypt and its allies?
options: To demonstrate that He alone is LORD and to punish idolatry and false security
Because Egypt was a chosen nation
To reward Egypt for their faithfulness
To establish Egypt as God’s holy city
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate that He alone is LORD and to punish idolatry and false security
questions.explanation: Throughout Ezekiel 30 (verses 8, 19, 25, 26), God’s judgment is meant to reveal His sovereignty and punish sin, especially idolatry and pride. This parallels the message in Isaiah 45:22-23, Psalm 97:1, Jeremiah 10:10, and Romans 1:18-23.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 30 illustrate the theme of divine wrath and mercy in biblical theology?
options: God’s wrath is executed to bring nations to know Him, indicating mercy through revelation
God’s wrath is arbitrary and without purpose
God shows mercy by ignoring sin
God’s wrath is final with no hope of restoration
questions.correctAnswer: God’s wrath is executed to bring nations to know Him, indicating mercy through revelation
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase ‘they shall know that I am the LORD’ (verses 8, 19, 25, 26) shows judgment serves redemptive purposes, revealing God’s mercy through revelation. This is consistent with Romans 2:4, Isaiah 30:18, Ezekiel 36:23, and 2 Peter 3:9.
